Support the Unitarians in Corrientes

For a long time, two projects of country divided Argentina. Unitarianists or Unitarians were the proponents of the concept of a Unitary state (centralized government) in Buenos Aires and they were led by  Juan Lavalle. They were opposed to the Argentine Federalists, who wanted a federation of independent provinces, led by Juan Manuel de Rosas. The Unitarians, sympathetic to our government, fled Argentina in exile after being defeated in 1831. Rosas, the so called Restorer of the Laws, controlled the Argentine Confederation for too long under his despotic rule. Now, our friends in Uruguay defeated the Blancos and promise to support us if we were to fight the Federalists to end Rosas despotic ruler.

We can't say that Corrientes was always the most loyal province. Despite being one of the founding members of the Federal League and part of the League of the Free Peoples under Artigas, Corrientes had a hard time joining the Federal League in the first place and, through the 1840's, Corrientes would fall under Unitarian control 4 times, with it even rising up a 5th time in support of Urquiza in Entre Rios, with this revolt being successful in removing Rosas. 

But now, be it under the command of Astrada, Ferré, Lavalle or even Madariaga, we need to crush the Unitarian revolt of Corrientes, before they solifidy their position in Mesopotamia.
Send Varela to Europe

§RVarela will be assassinated in march 1848, so be sure to take this decision before that!§! The Unitarians during the Big War counted not only with the support of Uruguay but also limited Anglo-French support. While both nations couldn't wage direct war with Rosas without allies to the ground, we could send Florencio Varela to negotiate with France and Britain for support, with the permission to take desperate measures if needed.

While they aren't directly involved on land, the British and the French are big supporters of Riveira in their interests of getting allies in the region against Rosas. Thus, in our current struggle against the Federalists currently in Buenos Aires, we sent Francisco Varela to England and France to gather support from these two European powers to aid in our struggle against Rosas. While our first offer would be to grant them free navigation through the Uruguay and Paraná rivers, we wouldn't be opposed to offer them a protectorate over Mesopotamia, if the situation is dire enough for that. 

So, what is Varela willing to offer to London and Paris?

\n\nOur involvement in the war between Rosas and Riveira has been limited at best, with the Anglo-French Blockade over Argentina starting over the Siege of Montevideo, but the situation has taken quite an interesting turn. While we were busy preventing Oribe from storming Montevideo, Riveira has went ahead and promoted an Uniratian revolt in Corrientes. The Uniratians were exiles from Argentina after their defeat in 1831, but now they come to us with an offer: in exchange from our full support in the war of independence against Rosas, they will grant us a protectorate over their new "Republic of Mesopotamia". While this may damage our relations in the region, it would fulfill our goals of opening up navigation on the Paraná and Uruguay rivers...

\n\nThe $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ have reportedly accepted our offer and declared war on Rosas and the Argentine Confederation. Now it is only a matter of time before Mesopotamia is recognized as Unitarian territory!

\n\nThe $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ have reportedly rejected our offer, with Varela's offer leading them to declare that the Unitarians ambitions in Mesopotamia went against their interests in the region, withdrawing all support towards us.

\n\nAfter a brief campaign in Argentina, it seems that Rosas and his army managed to repel all of our attempts to invade Argentina, leading to our defeat. After a prolonged period of outright war between our nations we sign peace with the Argentine dictator, hoping to recover from this humiliation

\n\nOnce again we managed to win—against all odds—a war against an European war. Despite their attempts to establish a protectorate over Mesopotamia the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ have been defeated and their blockade over Argentina has been lifted.

\n\nDespite Rosas best efforts, it seems that, unlike Spain, the British and France forces couldn't be as easily beaten. The Unitarians have managed to establish a nation in Mesopotamia and, with the protection of an European power, we would hardly be ever able to reintegrate them into Argentina.
\n\nIt seems that we managed to deal a significant blow the the Federalist government in Buenos Aires, leading Rosas to sue for peace and accept our protectorate over Mesopotamia.

\n\nThe Unitarians have swayed the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ into declaring war against us, stating their intentions to not only free up navigation in the Paraná and Uruguay rivers, but also establish a protectorate in Mesopotamia.

\n\nOribe's war against Riveira didn't went well. Despite some initial victories and even being able to expel Riveira to Brazil, Riveira found allies in the tumultuous Rio-grandense Republic, which helped him return to Uruguay and inflict several blows to Oribe's government, imposing on him defeat after defeat. But the last blow wasn't dealt by Riveira, instead, during their blockade of Buenos Aires, the French have occupied Martín García Island, leading Oribe to "resign" and flee to Buenos Aires, surrendering the country to Riveira.

\n\nFollowing their occupation of Entre Rios, the currently occupying Corrientes approached us with a proposal: in exchance for end of hostilities between us, they wish to have the independence of the Republic of Mesopotamia to be recognized. We can't say that that such an arrangement is to our liking, seeing as Mesopotamia is one of the most Federalist regions in the country, severely hurting our political position, but we have been unable to destroy Corrientes' armies, forcing us to accept their deal.

\n\nAfter a prolonged conflict with Rosas, we ended up in an uneasy stalemate. Our repeated revolts managed to exhaust Rosas' army and, on top of that, with the revolts in the Interior in the interior, we have enough leverage to propose a deal: Rosas could keep the Confederation, but Corrientes would keep Mesopotamia, breaking off from the confederation and allowing it to open the Paraná and Uruguay rivers as a compensation to its allies, forming the Republic of Mesopotamia.

\n\nWhile the idea of a "Republic" in Mesopotamia isn't new, this is the first time we achieve true independence in the region, with the last "Republic of Entre Rios" being mostly a statement against the Unitarian government that sat in Buenos Aires at the time. But now the roles are flipped, with Mesopotamia being occupied by an Unitarian government and Buenos Aires by and Federalist one. Now, with our independence accepted by Buenos Aires, there is a small debate about what to call our nation: "Republic of Mesopotamia" or "Independent State of Litoral"?
Corrientes

\n\nWith the defeat of the 4th and final Unitarian Army in Corrientes and the other Unitarian revolts, the province is once again loyal to the Argentine Confederation and the Federalist cause. After changing governors many times during the conflict, now rises to power the General Benjamín Virasoro as the governor of the province. Having served under Governor Urquiza in his final campaign to retake Corrientes and being a staunch Federalist, we believe he has the experience and the loyalty to keep the province under Federal control for good this time.

\n\nDespite being able to defeat the 1st Unitarian Army of Corrientes by himself, the governor Pascual Echagüe suffered defeat at the hands of the 3rd Unitarian Army of Corrientes, leading to his removal as government and the appointment of Justo José de Urquiza as Governor of Entre Rios. Despite some initial setbacks at the hands of the 3rd Army of Corrientes and even condemned by Rosas, Urquiza would ultimately be successful in defeating the Unitarists for good at the Battle of Vences. Luckily, Entre Rios—with the blockade of Argentina's only port—managed to get quite wealthy, but now, with the blockade lifted, the trade dominance of Buenos Aires is once again bothering the provinces of the Litoral.

On May 1st, 1851, General and Governor Justo José de Urquiza, unsatisfied with the lack of the return of the trade-primacy of Buenos Aires after the end of the Anglo-French Blockade and Rosas lack of a proper constitution for the Argentine Confederation decreed the Urquiza's Statement, on which he formally accepted Rosas resignation—which he applied for every year, knowing his resignation as foreign relations minister would be rejected—declaring the effective independence of the Province of Entre Rios until a proper General Assembly for the writing of a constitution was called. \n\nUrquiza's Statement was supported by his political pupil Benjamín Virasoro—Governor of Corrientes—which until now was considered one of Rosas' partisans. Rosas, in the other hand, naturally rejected the statement.
Urquiza's Statement

\n\nIt seems that the Mesopotamia region is yet to find peace. Despite having beaten the Unitarian savages from Corrientes, it seems that now the traitors are find in our own party. General and Governor José Justo de Urquiza has just defied Rosas' Government in open revolt, consorting with our Brazilian and Uruguayan enemies, with Corrientes under Benjamín Virasoro following suit as well. It seems that Rosas' Confederation will have one last obstacle before it can finally have peace...
Entre Rios
Correntino
Entrerriano

With the "Ejército Grande" taking shape, it began to organize itself in Diamante, with the intention of crossing into the Province of Santa Fé, where governor Pascual Echagüe (who became Governor of Santa Fé after losing his position as Governor of Entre Rios) prepared a defense against Urquiza and his army. 

On a surprising turn of events, not only did Urquiza's Staff counted with naturals of Santa Fé who kept him updated on the situation across the Paraná River, but the cities of Santa Fé and Rosário both proclaimed support to Urquiza, forcing Echagüe to leave the province to regroup in Buenos Aires, leading Urquiza to take Santa Fé without bloodshed and the start of the war against Rosas!

\n\nWe have been ready for war ever since Urquiza released his statement, declaring effective independence from the Argentine Confederation. Due to the marshy terrain of Southern Entre Rios, we were sure that General Urquiza would attemp a crossing to Santa Fé first, which General Pascual Echagüe was in charge of. Echagüe left the city of Santa Fé itself to prepare to meet Urquiza after his crossing, but both the cities of Santa Fé and Rosário stabbed our government in the back, declaring their allegiance to Urquiza. Echagüe was forced to leave the province, with his men deserting him as he made his way to Buenos Aires, with only 300 men remaining by the time he got to Rosas. It is clear our change to put down this revolt is now or never, lest we risk more desertions from our men and other provinces...

\n\nHaving clashed with the Argentines all throughout the Uruguayan Civil War, we are now informed that General José Justo de Urquiza, Governor of the Entre Rios Province in the Argentine Confederation has declared war on Rosas, with the intention of deposing Rosas from the ruling of the Confederation. While Urquiza has once been our enemy, we can't deny that supporting him would benefit us, considering that we could arrange some concessions to disrupt Argentine hegemony over the Paraná and Uruguay rivers.

\n\nWhile our government stabilizes after our victory at the Battle of Caseros, we recieve news that back in Corrientes, a revolt has granted Gregorio Pujol control over the province. While we are a bit unsure about Pujol's loyalty to Urquiza's cause, he ultimately wouldn't bring Corrientes against the Argentine Confederation, not to mention that Benjamín Virasoro—the old Governor of Corrientes and right-hand man of Urquiza—doesn't seem to mind, considering his new role in the Confederation besides Urquiza.

\n\nDespite some initial setbacks, Rosas managed to beat the traitor José Justo de Urquiza and his army of Unitarian savages and foreign enemies. The Ejército Grande was shattered, with Brazil and Uruguay suing for peace, leaving Urquiza and his allies under our mercy. New governors are already being appointed to the provinces, with Rosas hoping that the Argentine Confederation can finally find some degree of peace now. While this incident has been dealt with, we can't deny that it brought into question some matters regarding the Federal Pact and national organizaiton, which Rosas will need to adress if he wants to solidify his legacy as the Father of the Argentine Confederation.

\n\nWith their momentum from the bloodless takeover of Santa Fé, Urquiza, together with his Uruguayan and Brazilian allies, managed to win the decisive Battle of Caseros, leading Rosas to resign and flee the country, effectively exiling him to England. With this great victory, Urquiza is left as the definitive master of the Argentine Confederation. Luckily, the general is already preparing the ground for a new constitutional convention, promoting the San Nicolás Agreement, setting the bases for the national organization of the future Argentine Constitution. Sadly, Buenos Aires refused to ratify the pact, leading to Urquiza to intervene in the province, putting down any dissent for the time being...

\n\nIt would seem that Urquiza's Federal Intervention on Buenos Aires wasn't enough to quell the Unitarian sentiment in the city. Urquiza left the city in the 8th of September to preside over the Constitutient Congress' sessions, and 3 days later, in the 11 September, a bloodless coup by took over Buenos Aires, with the new government in the city preparing to act against Urquiza!

\n\nDepiste our victories in the Litoral, the interior provinces of the Argentine Confederation seem to be having their fair share of trouble. Sensing the Federalist infighting, many Federalist governors in the interior were deposed, with one of the more worrying examples being found in the north, being of the provinces of Tucumán, Salta and Santiago del Esterro which—after changing hands a couple of times—all ended up under the control of an Unitarian alliance in the north, led by Manuel Taboada. Despite the calls for help from the Federalist governor of Tucumán—Celedonio Gutiérrez—against Manuel Taboada and his ally José María del Campo, Urquiza wasn't of much use, leading to del Campo's takeover of Tucumán and the persecution of Federalists in Tucumán.

\n\nEven with their overwhelming influence over the Santiago del Esterro and its neighboring provinces, the Northern Alliance under Manuel Taboada has finally come it is end, leading to more stability over the region. That is not to say that his Liberal Party is dead, sadly such an Unitarian tool can't hardly die as easily as Taboada.

The Argentine Constitution of $YEAR$ was promulgated by Provisional Director José Justo de Urquiza. Being the 3rd Argentine Constitution of the country, it would see more success than the 1st and 2nd constitutions—which both were proposed by Buenos Aires but failed to gain support from the other provinces. The Constitution was based on the Federal model and the Federal Party's ideas, on top of being heavily inspired by the United States Constitution and the pioneering ideas of Juan Bautista Alberdi. Its text granted high level of independence to the Argentine provinces, a strong executive branch government and a bicameral national congress. 

Less than a year after the promulgation of the constitution, Urquiza would assume office as the 1st President of the Argentine Confederation.
Taboada's Alliance
Unitarian-Federal Clashes

It seems that the victory against Rosas was only the first step for the new Argentine Confederation. While the armies of Buenos Aires were quick to be beaten and an ex-Rosist mutiny laid siege to the city, allying with Urquiza, such a siege appears to have no end in sight. 

We were already starved off of money to play our troops, but we hoped that the blockade of the city would make it fall soon enough. Sadly, such plans went down the drain once Commander John Halstead Coe accepted a bribe from the Buenos Aires' government in exchange for the surrender of the navy in favor of Buenos Aires. Now, with no prospect to ever finish the siege like that, we are forced to withdraw...

\n\nAfter a prolonged conflict with Rosas, we ended up in an uneasy stalemate. Urquiza's coffers were running dry and—despite having the money to fund his troops—Rosas's army was under severe disadvantage, due to Urquiza's Brazilian and Uruguayan auxiliaries. On top of that, with the lack of reinforcement's from the interior, Urquiza had enough leverage to propose a deal: Rosas could keep the Confederation, but Urquiza and his allies would break off from the Confederation, forming the Independent State of the Litoral.

\n\nAfter a prolonged conflict with Rosas, we ended up in an uneasy stalemate. Urquiza's coffers were running dry and—despite having the money to fund his troops—Rosas's army was under severe disadvantage, due to Urquiza's Brazilian and Uruguayan auxiliaries. On top of that, with the lack of reinforcement's from the interior, Urquiza had enough leverage to propose a deal: Rosas could keep the Confederation, but Urquiza and his allies would break off from the Confederation, forming the Independent State of the Litoral.

\n\nWhile the idea of a "Republic" in Mesopotamia isn't new, this is the first time we achieve true independence in the region, with the last "Republic of Entre Rios" being mostly a statement against the Unitarian government that sat in Buenos Aires at the time. While our ambition was to overthrow Rosas, both Urquiza and his allies are satisfied with having Mesopotamia under his control, leading to the free navigation of Paraná and Uruguay Rivers. Now, with our independence accepted by Buenos Aires, there is a small debate about what to call our nation: "Republic of Mesopotamia" or "Independent State of Litoral"?

\n\n$FROMCOUNTRY$ are proposing a border and navigation treaty to resolve some of our border disputes with them. It involves the cession of the Paraguayan Misiones in exchange for the recognition of Paraguayan independence, dropping all claims to Pilar and entering an alliance with them against the government in Buenos Aires. It also gives Paraguay rights to navigate through our rivers.

$FROMCOUNTRY$ accepted our proposal! Our troops are already withdrawing from Missiones and a small celebration is being held at the new border with $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ government officials to celebrate the start of a great friendship between our two nations! 

We hope they can help us dissuade Argentinian claims in the Chaco.

\n\n$FROMCOUNTRY$ rejected our proposal! With this potential ally rejecting our overtures, we are forced to further entrench our position between our hostile neighbors. We can only hope $FROMCOUNTRY$ isn't planning on attacking us instead.

§RGain 5 infamy§! Between foreign and personal interests, to some degree, Entre Rios independence from the Argentine Confederation was founded on bases of the wish to uphold the ideals of Federalism. To reinforce our place as the bastion of "True Federalism", we could—to some degree—claim to be the true successor to the League of the Free Peoples, the state that—under José Gervasio Artigas—gave birth to the Federalist movement in Argentina. Doing so would put us at odds with our old allies, which now occupy territory which was once part of the League and would also rekindle our hostilities with Buenos Aires, which not only may still claim to be successors to the League, but also hold the Province of Córdoba, which was also part of the League to some degree.
Claim the Mantle of the League of the Free Peoples
Legacy of the Juliana Republic

§RGain 5 infamy§! With the birth of the Uruguayan Federation and the integration of the Gauchos from Rio Grande do Sul, the old ties between Uruguay and the local population have been rekindled. Despite the differences between us and the local population, we faced a lot of sympathetic sentiment in the region, with some like-minded even offering to pull some strings to find support across the northern border, in Santa Catarina, to try and give us a chance to claim the region. Santa Catarina was once occupied by the Rio-Grandense Republic during the Ragamuffin War, with the Juliana Republic being established. With support from the Farrapos in Rio Grande do Sul, we could claim the region and shorten our border with Brazil significantly.
End Paraguay's Independence

§RGain 10 infamy§! During the Platine Wars of Independence, Paraguay's fate stood on the edge of a knife. At the start, during the First Junta of Buenos Aires, Manuel Belgrano tried to invade Paraguay to liberate it from Royalist forces. Not only Belgrano in that task but Artigas also tried to incorporate Paraguay in the League of the Free Peoples, an prospect that also found no success. With both failed attempts on the conquest of Paraguay by Platine forces, the country's independence was secured. But now—as we carry the mantle of the League of the Free Peoples—Paraguay stands as the only country—besides us—between Argentina and Brazil. Thus, conquering it would not only avenge Artigas' attempt, but also become a stronger buffer between the two giants that border us.
The Tower of Babel

Very little progress has been made in the past few thousand years on that greatest of all building projects initiated by our proud ancestors. With Mesopotamia's recent ascent to power and standing in the world, there is some talk... though all talk has been strangely hard to understand lately... of starting the project back up again! With modern technology, who knows what wonders could be accomplished?
French: Au cours des derniers millénaires, très peu de progrès ont été faits sur le plus grand projet de construction initié par nos illustres ancêtres. Avec la montée en puissance récente et la nouvelle place dans le concert des nation de l'Iraq, on parle - même si récemment, le discourt s'est fait incompréhensible - de relancer le projet ! Avec la technologie moderne, qui sait quelles merveilles pourraient être accomplies ?
German: Im Laufe der letzten Jahrtausende wurden beim größten aller Bauprojekte, begonnen von unseren stolzen Vorfahren, kaum noch Fortschritte erzielt. Durch den kürzlichen Aufstieg des Iraks zu Macht und Ansehen in der Welt gibt es Gespräche ... die in letzter Zeit merkwürdigerweise nur schwer zu verstehen waren ... das Projekt wieder aufzunehmen! Welche Wunder wohl durch den Einsatz moderner Technologie möglich wären?
Spanish: En los últimos milenios apenas se han hecho progresos en el mayor de los proyectos de construcción iniciado por nuestros orgullosos antepasados. ¡Con el reciente ascenso de Irak en el concierto de las naciones, cada vez más voces (aunque cada vez más confusas, también es cierto) hablan de reiniciar el proyecto! Con la tecnología moderna, ¿quién sabe qué maravillas se podrían alcanzar?

English: \n\nNot long after the Argentine Confederation under Urquiza sanctioned their new constitution, the newly-independent State of Buenos Aires was sure to follow suit and sanction their own constitution. While the document doesn't outright declared independence from the Argentine Confederation, it leaves clear that Buenos Aires won't join the Confederation, unless it has the right to revise the Confederation's Constitution before joining.

\n\nWhile Federalism triumphed over Unitarism with the readmission of Buenos Aires into the Argentine Confederation, that is not to say that Federalism was quite safe. In the recent years, as the Argentine Confederation evolves, the old caudillos that were the heads of the Federalist Party are less and less able to gather power and influence, effectively changing the party's dynamics in the last few years. With the declining power of the caudillos, the party started to enjoy new factions, threatening to break away the party, the most relevant of which being the National Autonomists, the head of which is Nicolás Avellaneda, who is not only aligned with important figures like Alberdi, but is also a proponent of the institutional modernization of the Confederation. Should Avellaneda take over the Federalist party, he is sure to let Federalism evolve to something better suited for the years to come.

Despite his involvement in the 1830 Sedition, by the 1840's, as the liberal revolutions ravaged Europe, Samuel Gottfried Kerst was back in Germany to witness the liberal revolutions that swept across his fatherland. There he would become an active player in Prussian politics, working for its administration until it coming at odds with Prussia naval strategy. After falling out with the Prussian Navy, Kerst would become member of the Prussian Parliament and then a newspaper editor. 

More recently, Kerst has published a series of works about German immigration to Brazil and the Rio Grandense Republic, promoting waves of German immigration, to Brazil's detriment.
Repaying the favor

When Rivera—with help from his Anglo-French backers—deposed Oribe, Rosas was the man which not only hosted Oribe in exile, but also went to war to restore Oribe to the Uruguayan presidency. Now, as Oribe sits at the head of the Uruguayan politics once again, Rosas is facing problems back home, with the governor of Entre Rios—José Justo de Urquiza—revolting against him. It is about time we return the favor and help Rosas against this insurgency.

\n\nWhen Rivera—with help from his Anglo-French backers—deposed Oribe, Rosas was the man which not only hosted Oribe in exile, but also went to war to restore Oribe to the Uruguayan presidency. We are not surprised to know that now, as Urquiza wages a war against Rosas, Manuel Oribe has declared full support to Rosas, declaring war on Urquiza and his allies.

\n\nWhen Rivera—with help from his Anglo-French backers—deposed Oribe, Rosas was the man which not only hosted Oribe in exile, but also went to war to restore Oribe to the Uruguayan presidency. We are not surprised to know that now, as Urquiza wages a war against Rosas, Manuel Oribe has declared full support to Rosas, declaring war on Urquiza and his allies.

\n\nWith our triumph against the traitorous Urquiza, we can't overlook the help Manuel Oribe provided us by being quick to declare war against Urquiza. Rosas can't help but consider if a closer relationship with Oribe's Uruguay would be in order, an idea that was tossed around before, but post-ponned by Urquiza's revolt. With Anglo-French influence expelled from Uruguay, no one could oppose us if we were to sign a treaty declaring Oribe to the governor of the Provincia Oriental.

\n\nWith our triumph against the traitorous Urquiza, Rosas couldn't help but see the value Oribe had been to his Confederation. Naturally, seeking to deepen their partnership, Rosas proposed to Oribe that Uruguay join the Argentine Confederation, with him as its provicial governor, of course.

\n\nMany of the men who fought under Urquiza against Rosas wanted one thing and one thing only, a democratic constitution for the Argentine Federation. While we have little hope of implementing such a constitution on the Argentine Confederation—still under Rosas—with our independence, we can at least let our people bear fruit of such ideas. With nothing in his way, Urquiza called for a constitutional congress in Santa Fé, which has just finished the final draft of the Constitution of $COUNTRY$, following our federalist and democratic ideals.

\n\nDespite our allies planning to do a naval invasion of Santa Fé from Sacramento, General Justo José de Urquiza, with the help of his Uruguayan and Brazilian auxiliaries, managed to beat Rosas at the Battle of Monte Caseros, which prompted the Argentine tyrant to flee from the battlefield to Buenos Aires, where he would disguise himself and embark on a ship out of the country, effectively exiling himself and handing over the country to Urquiza.

\n\nOur relations with our southern neighbors aren't the best. Argentina has tried—and failed—to invade our nation in the past and they still claim that we are just a rebelious province of their confederation. While the current head of the confederation Juan Manuel de Rosas is set on one day reconquering Paraguay, a revolt has broken on the other side of the border, with the Province of Corrientes being currently controlled by Unitarians that oppose his government. While they already count with Uruguayan support, giving them further support would only weaken Rosas and maybe provide us with leverage to negotiate our independence with the Unitarians in the future.
The Death of Rosas
Implement Angelis' Constitution

The traitor José Justo de Urquiza once commissioned journalist and historian Pedro de Angelis a constitution. While Urquiza was defeated by our great leader Rosas, the constitutional project went ahead, with the finished 135-long constitution being published in Angelis' journal in Buenos Aires. Rosas—at first—personally wasn't very keen on Angelis and his work, but with time our great leader approached Angelis personally to publish some intellectual projects of his government, creating a bridge between the two men. \n\nWith Rosismo evolving and Rosas' health starting to fade, it may be for the best that—instead of relying on Rosas' son to carry his regime on—we commission Angelis' constitution to be sanctioned as the official constitution of the Argentine Confederation.

Princess Alice arrival in Buenos Aires was a celebrated one. It was hard to convince the English government to let Alice be crowned Queen of Argentina, but—after guaranteeing Alice would reign as a constitutional monarch—the British Royal Family accepted letting Alice be our queen. 

Just like that, today, on the year of our Lord $YEAR$, Alice Maud Mary, also known as Princess Alice of the United Kingdom, was crowned as Queen Alice I, of the Saxe-Coburg-Gotta dynasty, first queen of the Argentine Monarchy. Long live the Queen!

\n\nSadly, for one reason or another, the British Royal Family refused to let Princess Alice be crowned Alice I of Argentina. While this is quite a setback to Rosas monarchical plans, maybe, if he is so set on following this path, the dictator could declare himself Protector of Argentina and Restorer of the Order, granting him the title of king Juan Manuel de Rosas I, the first of the Rosas dynasty, first king of the Argentine Monarchy.
Cut Negotiations with Paraguay

§RGain 10 infamy§! "Relations with the Province of Paraguay, which have been severed for many years, will be definitively restored by the first Legislative Congress that meets after the present Constitution is sworn in." — These are the exact words in Angelis' Constitution. While vague, Angelis confessed—at a later date—to including it as a path to reintegrate Paraguay into the Confederation. Paraguay has long been a great reason of shame and a thorn in our side, with its dictator—Carlos Antonio López—having supported both the Unitarians in Corrientes and the traitors under Urquiza. But—following Angelis draft—we have established negotiations with Asunción which have yet to be fruitful. Maybe it is about time we cut off our relations with Paraguay and end their independence once and for all.
Interim Government of Colombia
\n\nWith out victory against the secessionists, the new reformist government can declare itself the "Interim Government of Colombia", with the hope of soon reforming an unified Colombia.

\n\nSadly, be it by our idleness or our failure to unite Colombia by force, the reformist spirit that started the reformist revolt has long since faded, leaving us to officially drop the claims to an unified colombian state once for the time being.

\n\nThe French Blockade, while not enough to make us kneel under its weight, surely hit our nation quite hard, so much so that the landowners of Buenos Aires started to conspire with our French and Unitarian enemies to depose our great leader from Buenos Aires. This conspiracy was able to reach Rosas' personal friend, Manuel Vincente Maza, whose son was chosen as son of said conspiracy. As the conspirators were ready to strike, Rosas managed to arrest Maza's son, which—after supposedly trying to help his son—was assassinated in his office, with his son being executed in the next day. With that, the revolt lost the support in Buenos Aires itself, with it being limited to a small army in the south of Buenos Aires. The army was meant to be lead by Juan Galo de Lavalle, the old Unitarian governor of Buenos Aires, but he ended up being leading his army into Entre Rios, were he found some degree of success, leaving the revolt in Buenos Aires to fight on its own.

\n\nOnce, the interior was safely under the rule of Facundo Quironga. But ever since his death in 1835, things began to change. Governors of the interior provinces began to slowly be swayed to the Unitarian cause, leading to a small revolt by Domingo Cullen, which was swiftly dealt with by governor Juan Pablo López—of Santa Fé. Now, with the war against Corrientes waging on another bigger, more threatening revolt, has come to be, with the governor of Tucumán—Marco Manuel Avellaneda—rallying an coalition against Rosas, joining forces with the governors of Salta, Jujuy, Catamarca and La Roja. Rosas tried to prevent the uprising by seizing Tucumán's guns, but the general he sent—Gregorio Aráoz de Lamadrid—joined forces with the coalition—due to his Unitarian background.
Northern Coalition

Our old disputes with the Federalist Party led to our secession from the old Argentine Confederation. With the fall of the Federalist government, the Unitarians took over Argentina, destroying the old confederation and declared the creation of the Argentinian Republic, which closely alligns with our ideals. Perhaps now it's time we finally rejoin Buenos Aires...

\n\nWhen Alto Peru was incorporated in the Argentine Confederation, it was bound to have a special status. Since then, Argentine politics have slowly sapped into Bolivia, with disputes between Unitarians and Federalists also happening in Alto Peru, as they also happened in the Argentine Interior. Together with the governors of La Roja, Santa Fé and—of course—Buenos Aires, the Governor of Alto Peru was one of the pivotal federalist governors in the confederation. But recently, the old governor left the office, giving way to a new governor, less alligned with Rosas and his ideals. Now, be it for a desire to trully support the Bolivian people, to support the Unitarians or pure madness, the new governor of Alto Peru has declared, in La Paz, war on Rosas and his Federalist confederation, rallying the Bolivian people to his side. Sadly, we can't say that the entire country followed the governor's idea, with provinces like Tarija and Salta regrettably declaring loyalty to the confederation, taking arms against us.

\n\nWhen Alto Peru was incorporated in the Argentine Confederation, it was bound to have a special status. The governor of Alto Peru was—among the governors of La Roja, Santa Fé and, of course, Buenos Aires—one of the most important governors in the Argentine Confederation. But after serving us truthfully, the governor of Alto Peru was deposed by one of his subordinates, which now, in our moment of weakness, has declared war on Rosas, trying to have Bolivia to rule as his little fiefdom. Luckily, some of Alto Peru sees this madness and chooses to take arms against the mad caudillo, declaring allegiance to governor Rosas and his confederation.

\n\nThe Army of North was victorious! Our role in the downfall of the Peru-Bolivian Confederation—despite being somewhat limited—earned us the opportunity to take a few spoils from this war. While it would be in our ultimate interest to make Bolivia join our great nation—as it was once part of the Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata—our role in the war was far too small for such a prize. But, that is not to say we are to leave empty handed, as we hold solve some contested claims with Bolivia, or even look into some of their territory which we could annex. Besides our claims in Tarija and Susquis, we also could also annex the Bolivian ports in Antofagasta, which were once part of the Province of Salta. On top of that, one of the ideas we had during the war was to sack Potosí and its mint, luckily, this idea wouldn't come to fruition, but maybe it wouldn't be a bad idea to take the city and its mint for ourselves, considering it was responsible for our minting first coins. Annexing any of these territories for ourselves its bound to make mortal enemies out of the Bolivians, no doubt.

\n\nRivera, by igniting a revolt in Corrientes, led to a general Unitarian uprising across Argentina, with revolts Rosas' regime facing revolts in the Interior and Buenos Aires. Regrettably, one of the campaigns had to be fought over Alto Peru, where—to our surprise—we faced some support, despite the betrayal coming from the local governor. Provinces like Tarija and Salta came to our aid in our hour of need and now, as the dust settles, they ask for deeper ties with the Argentine Confederation, wanting to be a direct part of the Confederation, rather than being under Alto Peru.

The Rights of the First Peoples

While we can't say the Federalist Party is ideologically alligned with the idea of indigenous rights, our ideology and political structure always favored great cooperation with the local indigenous peoples. Artigas was the first to do so, with his policies and networks reaching the indigenous peoples. Besides that, as the Federalist model favored local power, Federalist caudillos were quick to use the local natives to their advantage, not to mention that nods to the native population weren't an exclusive Federalist phenomenon, with the declaration of independence by the Congress of Tucumán being published in Spanish, Quechua and Aimara.
Colorado Victory

\n\nDespite our best efforts, the Army of the North was defeated! While we expected an easy conflict against an unstable confederation, it seems that our defeat was assured one way or the another, which Chile faring no better. We now wait for the Confederation's terms, maybe they will go easy on us, after all that happened.

\n\nHaving defeated the Argentinian Army of North, our Confederation stands victorious! Our enemies expected a weak and unstable confederation, but they were gravely mistaken and it is now time we decide the price they will pay for it. While most argue we should just make our $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ neighbors drop our claims on us, there is the real possibility of getting some extra land out of this, at the cost of making an permanent enemy to the south. What was suggested is that we annex some of the Argentinian interior provinces, Jujuy and Salta, maybe Tucumán and Catamarca, all of which once had deep economic ties with us.

After the Revolution of the Restorers, Balcarce was succeed by Juan José Viamonte, which soon was forced to resign as well, leading to Manuel Vicente Maza to assume the Governorship of Buenos Aires, after no one else accepted the position. Maza—a friend of Rosas who participated in the Revolution of the Restorers—would soon have to resign as well, as in February he sent Federalist leader Facundo Quironga to settle a dispute in the Interior. On his way there, Quirong was assassinated, leading to such public outrage that he was forced to resign, with the House of Representatives of Buenos Aires finally yelding and electing Juan Manuel de Rosas to the governorship of the province, granting him the "sum of the public power" and thus dictatorial powers. 

Rosas would become the 17th Governor of Buenos Aires in the 13th of March.

\n\nWith the help of the Sociedad Popular Restauradora—and its parapolice unit, La Mazorca—Rosas managed to use state terrorism as a tool for his regime. La Mazorca would conduct raids into neighborhoods, persecuting anyone not deemed loyal enough to Rosas, accusing them of having ties to the Unitarians. Rosas would exercise full control of La Mazorca as a tool for terror, burning opposition newspapers and being sure to pick on the target which demise would be the most useful as a tool of terror, instead of carrying out its attacks randomly. In the end, most enemies of Rosas would end up having to exile themselves—usually to Montevideo, where they would find support with the Uruguayan colorados—leaving the Argentine dictator with full control over the Province of Buenos Aires.

\n\nRosas' new regime sought to control every aspect of public life, buildings were decorated in red, the color of Rosismo and Federalism, every public document held the inscription "Death to the Savage Unitarians" at the top of it, government employees were forced forced to wear a badge saying "Federation or Death" and every male and female had to sport a "federal look", with males being forced to grow moustaches and sideburns, not to mention the children also having to wear uniforms with the colors and motiffs of the new regime. The red color became omnipresent in Buenos Aires as a constant reminder of Rosas and his regime.

\n\nThe dictorial powers granted by holding "the sum of public power" allowed Rosas to create an elaborate cult of personality around himself, letting him be portrayed as almighty protector of the people. His portraits were carried out on the street in demonstrations and then put on the church alter to be venerated. Rosas had the backing of most Catholic clergy, especially since most of them were on the state's payroll, since the Catholic Church had refused to acknowledge Argentinian independence, letting the government invest their own men into the churches and parishes of Buenos Aires, with the only clergy which opposed Rosas—the Jesuits—being expelled from the country as was most opposition to Rosas.

\n\nRosas came to control various aspects of everyday life for the people of Buenos Aires, forcing people to adhere to Federalism and Rosismo even in the way they wore their clothes. Not only that, but he also managed to enjoy some popularity with both Afro-Argentines and Gauchos, being admired for his willingness to mingle with these marginalized groups of Argentine society. That is not to say that Rosas was all-benevolent—much to the contrary—those who had the courage to oppose him are now dead, castrated or living across the Rio de La Plata in Montevideo. Rosas' hegemony over the politics of Buenos Aires is unmatched.
Paternal Totalitarianism

Our great leader holds total authority over the society and seeks to control all aspects of public and private life wherever possible, seeing himself as a "benevolent dictator" and a father to our people. He reaches so far as to dictate how people dress and carry themselves, plastering the symbols of the regime all over the country. In contrast, anyone opposed to his absolute authority is forced into hiding, or faces punishment in prison or even is made an example by our leader's agents. The entire population is, willingly or unwillingly, conscripted to serve our leader's priorities and subject to his whims.
\n\nDespite our best attempts to overthrow Rosas, our effort has been in vain, we were unable and retake Buenos Aires for the Unitarian cause and our revolt is over.

\n\nRecently our armies have marched to occupy the region of the Chaco. The region is currently pending incorporation in our nation, with the Province of Santa Fé laying claim to part of it. Sadly the region is also claimed by Argentina, leading to some of our advisors to suggest that we propose a treaty to our neighbors, splitting the Chaco along a straight line along Santa Fé's claims, keeping everything to its east. This would prevent any future conflict with out neighbor due to our conflicting claims to the Chaco.

\n\nRecently, $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ armies have marched to occupy the region of the Chaco. As we also claim the region, we had already started to draw plans to recover the region from them, but it seems that they predicted that the region could cause conflict between our countries, with their diplomats reaching us to propose a treaty splitting the Chaco, offering to give us all the land west of Santa Fé's claims to the land, which would grant us about half of the territory they came to occupy.

\n\nOur diplomats came back from the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ capital, informing that the treaty was a success! As our troops leave part of the Chaco, we can sleep easier at night knowing that we have one less reason to fight our neighbors.

Seeing as we were unable to defeat them once and for all, we have no option but to accept that Buenos Aires is out of our reach and that we are better off learning to live without them as part of the Argentine Confederation.
A Capital for the Confederation

Until now, Paraná has been the Federal capital of the Argentine Confederation ever since Rosas was deposed and Buenos Aires broke away from us. But now, with the matter of Buenos Aires dealt with, it is finally time we decide on a definitive capital for the Argentine Confederation, lest the savages in Buenos Aires find a way to let their city be our capital once again.

\n\nWe can't deny that which ever city takes the place as the official capital of the Confederation has big shoes to fill, especially with how it will have to fight to stay more influential than Buenos Aires, while at the same time not being overbearing on the provinces. One of the options, of course, is to keep the capital in Paraná, which would save on the work of moving our administration anywhere. One popular option is to move the capital to Rosário, which is better suited to be the capital of the nation, or even moving the capital to Tucumán, to appeal to the Interior. On the other hand, some people argue that we would need a newly-built city to serve as the capital to trully eclipse Buenos Aires as our administrative center!

\n\nHaving decided to build a new city from the ground up, there are a few options of were to do it. We could build a new city in the La Plata River, bearing the same name—La Plata—or even a city on the Paraná River—Federación. Another option, far from the La Plata River would be a city in the south—Belgrano. And last, but not lest, if we were to stay away from the coast, our final option would somewhere in the interior—the city of Unión.

Positivist Oligarchy

Our country is currently ruled by a governmental and intellectual elite of positivist oligarchs that are bent on staying on power by any means necessary—while keeping the guise of a democratic government, of course.

After the presidencies of Mitre, Sarmiento and Avellaneda, Júlio Argentino Roca—as the 4th President of the Argentine Republic—set the stage for the political climate in Argentina for the next few decades, giving way for the Generation of '80, the governing and intellectual elite that dominated Argentinian politics under the National Autonomist Party for well over 30 years. During the uncontested rule of the National Autonomist Party, Argentina found itself influced by the positivist ideas of Comte, with governance being carried with optimism and the idea that the country would grow in every aspect (be it economically, socially or culturally), let there be created the conditions for it grow. 

The period was also market by the crackdown on provincial autonomy, leading to provicial identities fading away with time and the country becoming more centralized.

After the fall of the Confederation, Mitre has an easy time subjulgating the Interior—apart from Mendonza, most provinces fell without putting much of a fight. But that wouldn't mean that Federalism was quite dead in the Interior—far from it. The Revolution of the Colorados was the last Federalist revolt in the Interior, happening right in the middle of the Paraguayan War, with the provinces of Mendoza, San Luis, San Juan and La Rioja falling to the revolt, with it also finding some support in provinces such as Catamarca, Cordoba, Corrientes and Santa Fé. 

To our luck, Urquiza—the Federalist Leader and Governor of Entre Rios—refrained from showing support to the revolt, despite the plea from the Federalist leaders, else we would risk finding ourselves returning to Federalist rule.

With Urquiza's silence in face of the Federalist revolt in the Interior, one of his old generals—Ricardo Ramón López Jordán—would turn against him, slowly plotting his revenge. On the 11th of April Jordán would revolt with a botched attempt to arrest Urquiza, which would result in the death of the Federalist leader. After that Jordán would assume as Governor of Entre Rios, but President Sarmiento would see this as an challenge to his authority, prompting him to send a troop of veterans to Entre Rios, expelling Jordan from the province. 

Jordán would continue to clash with the Unitarian government until his arrest in the 16th of December 1876. He would later escape prision and exile himself in Montevideo, until returning in 1888 after being given amnesty, only to be assassinated in 1889. After the end of his revolt, Federalism would be dead, with its last remaining followers assimilating into Alsina's Autonomist Party.

\n\nWhen a constitution was finally implemented, no one thought that Rosas would willingly give his power like that. The Restorer of Laws was always quick to steer politics into his interests, believing himself to be a benevolent dictator to his people. Something seems to really have changed. Rosas has officially stepped down for power as 1st President of the Argentine Confederation, giving way to a new politician who will be sure to be influenced by him to some degree. Regardless, this still dawns a new day for the Argentine Confederation, a day many waited for with for a long time.

\n\nWith Rosas gone it seems that many of his old allies feared that Juan wouldn't be as competent or friendly as his father was and such—together with an influx of old Unitarians seeing Rosas' death as the opportunity to return to Buenos Aires—have organized a revolt against Juan in Buenos Aires, expelling the Federal government from the city and forcing us to take action against our own capital.

\n\nWe would be lying if we didn't say the news of Rosas' death didn't bring us joy to some degree. Sadly, we now learn that his death brough upon the Confederation a revolt by the Unitarians, leading to the new Federal government having to declare war on the capital in Buenos Aires. While we can't help but feel that is the natural outcome of giving that much power to Buenos Aires, maybe we could make the most of the situation and return to the Confederation, leading it to victory against the Unitarians one last time.

\n\nThe separation of the Litoral from Argentina was controversial, for sure. But it was a necessary measure against Rosas Totalitarianism. Now, with Rosas gone there is nothing in the way of reunifying our two nations, especially if the democratic advancements from the Litoral are implemented in the rest of the country.

\n\nWith the Federal triumph over all of Argentina's enemies, it is about time we consolidate our rule. After everything that happened, some administrative reforms are needed to let our country be better suited to run under its current leadership.
